reasoning:
Essay B is significantly better than Essay A in all aspects of Criterion B: Exploration. Essay B's research question, "How does varying temperature... affect the oscillation pattern and duration of a Belousov–Zhabotinsky (BZ)...chemical oscillator...?", is focused, complex, and clearly defines the independent, dependent, and control variables with specific values and uncertainties. In contrast, Essay A's research question is awkwardly phrased as a statement of intent and lacks clarity. Furthermore, Essay B provides extensive and relevant background information, contextualizing the BZ reaction with real-world phenomena (cardiac arrhythmia), explaining the underlying redox chemistry, and linking the investigation to reaction kinetics via collision theory and Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions. Essay A's background is almost non-existent, merely defining titration in a single sentence.

The methodological design in Essay B is exemplary; it includes a section justifying the choice of a lux sensor over other measurement tools, demonstrating thoughtful preliminary work. It also provides a comprehensive table that not only lists controlled variables but also explains why and how they will be controlled, a critical feature that is entirely absent in Essay A. Essay A's procedure is an incomplete list of steps with no justification for the method or quantities used. Finally, while both essays include risk assessments, Essay B's is more thorough, detailing the specific risks of each chemical and including a commendable environmental consideration by explaining the decision to reduce the scale of the experiment to minimize waste. Essay A's safety section is adequate but lacks this level of detail and thoughtfulness.

Furthermore, Essay B provides extensive and relevant background information, contextualizing the BZ reaction with real-world phenomena (cardiac arrhythmia), explaining the underlying redox chemistry, and linking the investigation to reaction kinetics via collision theory and Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions. Essay A\'s background is almost non-existent, merely defining titration in a single sentence.\n\nThe methodological design in Essay B is exemplary; it includes a section justifying the choice of a lux sensor over other measurement tools, demonstrating thoughtful preliminary work. It also provides a comprehensive table that not only lists controlled variables but also explains why and how they will be controlled, a critical feature that is entirely absent in Essay A. Essay A\'s procedure is an incomplete list of steps with no justification for the method or quantities used. Finally, while both essays include risk assessments, Essay B\'s is more thorough, detailing the specific risks of each chemical and including a commendable environmental consideration by explaining the decision to reduce the scale of the experiment to minimize waste. Essay A\'s safety section is adequate but lacks this level of detail and thoughtfulness.',
    decision='essay_b'
)
